Steps.Procedure: Used unicode right-to-left override (RTLO) character to obfuscate file name rcs.3aka3.doc (originally cod.3aka.scr)
Steps.Criteria: Evidence of the right-to-left override character (U+202E) in the rcs.3aka.doc process ​OR the original filename (cod.3aka.scr)

Detections.DetectionNote: A Technique alert detection (medium severity) for Masquerading was generated due to Right-to-Left -Override (RLO) technique being observed on rcs.3aka3.doc

Steps.Procedure: Masqueraded a Chrome password dump tool as accesscheck.exe, a legitimate Sysinternals tool
Steps.Criteria: Evidence that accesschk.exe is not the legitimate Sysinternals tool

Detections.DetectionNote: A General alert detection was generated for accesschk.exe being detected as "Hacktool:Win32/ChromePassRecovery.A."
Telemetry showed hash of accesschk.exe, which can be used to verify it is not the legitimate Sysinternals tool.

Steps.Procedure: Established WinRM connection to remote host Scranton (10.0.1.4)
Steps.Criteria: Network connection to Scranton (10.0.1.4) over port 5985

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed a connection to Scranton (10.0.1.4) over TCP port 5985.

Steps.Procedure: Established a WinRM connection to the domain controller host NewYork (10.0.0.4)
Steps.Criteria: Network connection to NewYork (10.0.0.4) over port 5985

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed powershell.exe making a network connection to remote host NewYork (10.0.0.4) over port 5985.

Steps.Procedure: Established a WinRM connection to the remote host Scranton (10.0.1.4) using the Golden Ticket as credentials
Steps.Criteria: Network connection to Scranton (10.0.1.4) over port 5985

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for Lateral Movement was generated containing evidence a new PowerShell session was initiated from host Utica (10.0.1.5) to Scranton (10.0.1.4) and a session was created under the local administrator account (RID 500).
Telemetry showed PowerShell with an open network connection to the remote host Scranton (10.0.1.4) over port 5985.

Steps.Procedure: Created Kerberos Golden Ticket using Invoke-Mimikatz
Steps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing Invoke-Mimikatz with command-line arguments to create a golden ticket

Detections.DetectionNote: A Technique alert detection (medium severity) for Suspected Golden Ticket Usage was generated by Azure ATP due to mscott using a weaker encryption method (RC4) in the Kerberos service request.

Steps.Procedure: Spawned interactive cmd.exe
Steps.Criteria: cmd.exe spawning from the rcs.3aka3.doc​ process

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed cmd.exe spawning from rcs.3aka3.doc​. This event was correlated to a Technique detection for masquerading.

Steps.Procedure: Enumerated anti-virus software using PowerShell

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing:​ Get-WmiObject ...​ -Class AntiVirusProduct. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Steps.Procedure: Enumerated firewall software using PowerShell

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing:​ Get-WmiObject ...​ -Class FireWallProduct. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Steps.Procedure: Enumerated registered AV products using PowerShell
Steps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing a Get-WmiObject query for AntiVirusProduct

Detections.DetectionNote: A General alert detection (medium severity) was generated for script with suspicious content.
Telemetry showed PowerShell gwmi query for AntiVirusProduct.

Steps.Procedure: Read the Chrome SQL database file to extract encrypted credentials

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for Credential Access was generated containing evidence the Chrome database was read from the machine using accesschk.exe.

Steps.Procedure: Modified the time attributes of the kxwn.lock persistence payload using PowerShell
Steps.Criteria: powershell.exe modifying the creation, last access, and last write times of kxwn.lock

Detections.DetectionNote: A General alert detection (medium severity) was generated for suspicious PowerShell commandline.
An MSSP detection for Timestomping was generated due to time attributes being modified on kxwn.lock.
Telemetry showed a timestamp modification event for kxwn.lock as well as specific time modifications. The activity is correlated to a previous General detection on kxwn.lock.

Steps.Procedure: Added a new user to the remote host Scranton (10.0.1.4) using net.exe

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for Lateral Movement was generated containing evidence a new user was created on Scranton with name 'toby'."
Telemetry showed addition of the new user Toby.

Steps.Procedure: Decompressed ZIP (SysinternalsSuite.zip) file using PowerShell

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed PowerShell decompressing the ZIP via Expand-Archive.

Steps.Procedure: Decoded an embedded DLL payload to disk using certutil.exe

Detections.DetectionNote: A Technique alert detection (medium severity) for "Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information" was generated due to certutil.exe decoding kxwn.lock.
Telemetry showed the certutil.exe process and corresponding file write of the kxwn.lock payload.

Steps.Procedure: Read and decoded Mimikatz output from a WMI class property using PowerShell

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed PowerShell reading encoded content from the WMI class. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view was shown.

Steps.Procedure: Dumped messages from the local Outlook inbox using PowerShell
Steps.Criteria: outlook.exe spawning from svchost.exe or powershell.exe

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for Suspicious Activity was generated containing evidence that PowerShell function 'psemail' was used to copy emails from an Outlook inbox.
Telemetry showed outlook.exe spawning from svchost.exe, which is indicative of programmatic access to Outlook emails.

Steps.Procedure: Used HTTPS to transport C2 (192.168.0.5) traffic
Steps.Criteria: Evidence that the network data sent over the C2 channel is HTTPS

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for Command and Control was generated containing evidence Meterpreter communications were being sent using HTTPS, due to the presence of the WINHTTP_FLAG_SECURE within the embedded shell code.

Steps.Procedure: Used HTTPS to transport C2 (192.168.0.4) traffic
Steps.Criteria: Established network channel over the HTTPS protocol

Detections.DetectionNote: No detection capability demonstrated for this procedure.

Steps.Procedure: Enumerated current running processes using PowerShell

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence that multiple local and domain reconnaissance operations were executed. Get-Process was specifically identified in the report.
Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing Get-Process.

Steps.Procedure: Enumerated the current process ID using PowerShell

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: $PID. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Steps.Procedure: Enumerated processes on remote host Scranton (10.0.1.4) using PowerShell

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed wsmprovhost.exe executing Get-Process.

Steps.Procedure: Checked that processes such as procexp.exe, taskmgr.exe, or wireshark.exe are not running using PowerShell
Steps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing a Get-WmiObject query for Win32_Process

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence PowerShell ran commands to get process information on the machine: gwmi -namespace root\cimv2 -query 'SELECT * FROM Win32_Process'.
Telemetry showed the PowerShell gwmi query for Win32_Process.

Steps.Procedure: Enumerated running processes using the CreateToolhelp32Snapshot API

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed PowerShell calling the CreateToolhelp32Snapshot API. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Steps.Procedure: Enumerated and tracked PowerShell processes using PowerShell

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed PowerShell executing Get-Process. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view was shown.

Steps.Procedure: Captured user keystrokes using the GetAsyncKeyState API

Detections.DetectionNote: A Technique alert detection for Input Capture (high severity) was generated due to powershell.exe using APIs that are commonly abused by malicious applications to log keystrokes.
Telemetry showed API calls for GetAsyncKeyState. Though no image was captured, MITRE confirmed that the vendor has the capability to show available telemetry in a separate view.

Steps.Procedure: Created a LNK file (hostui.lnk) in the Startup folder that executes on login
Steps.Criteria: powershell.exe creating the file hostui.lnk in the Startup folder

Detections.DetectionNote: A Technique alert detection (medium severity) for Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder was generated due to the file write of hostui.lnk in the Startup folder. This detection was correlated to a parent General detection of rcs.3aka3.doc being identified as 'patpoopy' backdoor.

A General alert detection (low severity) was generated for "a link file (LNK) with unusual characteristics was opened." This detection was correlated to a parent General detection that rcs.3aka3.doc was identified as a patpoopy.backdoor.
An MSSP detection for Persistence was generated due to hostui.lnk being placed inside the Startup folder.

Steps.Procedure: Executed LNK payload (hostui.lnk) in Startup Folder on user login
Steps.Criteria: Evidence that the file hostui.lnk (which executes hostui.bat as a byproduct) was executed from the Startup Folder

Detections.DetectionNote: No detection capability demonstrated for this procedure.
Footnotes: This activity would have been blocked by Microsoft Defender.

Steps.Procedure: Established Registry Run key persistence using PowerShell
Steps.Criteria: Addition of the Webcache subkey in HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for Execution was generated containing evidence a Registry key was created for persistence under HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.
Telemetry showed powershell.exe adding Run key persistence into the Registry.

Steps.Procedure: Established SMB session to remote host Scranton's (10.0.1.4) IPC$ share using PsExec
Steps.Criteria: SMB session to Scanton (10.0.1.4) over TCP port 445/135 OR evidence of usage of a Windows share

Detections.DetectionNote: Telemetry showed an SMB session from Nashua (10.0.1.6) to Scranton (10.0.1.4) over TCP 135.

Telemetry showed sdelete.exe running with command-line arguments to delete the file and the subsequent file rename and delete events.

Telemetry showed a registry event for the creation of javamtsup service.

Steps.Procedure: Established WMI event subscription persistence using PowerShell
Steps.Criteria: powershell.exe creating the WindowsParentalControlMigration WMI filter, consumer, and binding created in root/subscription

Detections.DetectionNote: A Technique alert detection (medium severity) for Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription was generated due to a WMI event filter being bound to a suspicious event consumer.

An MSSP detection for Persistence was generated containing evidence PowerShell commands were executed to use WMI to subscribe to the WindowsParentalControlMigration scheduled task start event for user 'Oscar'.
Telemetry showed the WindowsParentalControlMigration WMI filter, consumer, and binding created in root/subscription. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Steps.Procedure: Executed WMI persistence on user login

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for execution was generated containing evidence of the execution of malicious staging payload via WMI persistence, triggered by the logon of user Oscar.
Telemetry showed wmiprvse.exe executing the PowerShell stager.
Footnotes: This activity would have been blocked by Microsoft Defender configured with Attack Surface Reduction.

Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing:​ Invoke-NetUserGetGroups. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Telemetry showed the addition of the DelegateExecute Registry Value.

Steps.Procedure: Enumerated devices/adapters to check for presence of VirtualBox driver(s) using PowerShell
Steps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing a Get-WmiObject query for Win32_PnPEntity

Telemetry showed the PowerShell gwmi query for Win32_PnPEntity.

Steps.Procedure: Captured clipboard contents using PowerShell

Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing Get-Clipboard.

Telemetry showed powershell.exe connecting to 192.168.0.5 on TCP port 443.

Telemetry showed WmiPrvSE.exe executing powershell.exe.

Steps.Procedure: Captured and saved screenshots using PowerShell
Steps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing the CopyFromScreen function from System.Drawing.dll

Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing CopyFromScreen from System.Drawing.dll.

Steps.Procedure: Executed the CryptUnprotectedData API call to decrypt Chrome passwords

Detections.DetectionNote: An MSSP detection for Credential Access was generated containing evidence the CryptUnprotectData API was invoked in order to perform decryption on password data.

Steps.Procedure: Dumped password hashes from the Windows Registry by injecting a malicious DLL into Lsass.exe
Steps.Criteria: powershell.exe injecting into lsass.exe OR lsass.exe reading Registry keys under HKLM:\SAM\SAM\Domains\Account\Users\

Detections.DetectionNote: A General alert detection (medium severity) for "suspicious process injection was observed" was generated due to powershell.exe injecting into lsass.exe.
Telemetry shows powershell.exe using CreateRemoteThread API call to inject into lsass.exe.

Steps.Procedure: Dumped plaintext credentials using Mimikatz (m.exe)
Steps.Criteria: m.exe injecting into lsass.exe to dump credentials

Detections.DetectionNote: A Technique alert detection (high severity) for "Credential Dumping"  was generated for m.exe executing with command-line arguments indicative of Mimikatz credential dumping.
A Technique alert detection (medium severity) for "Credential Dumping"  was generated due to suspected credential theft activity.
Telemetry showed m.exe opening lsass.exe with OpenProcess.

Telemetry showed m.exe opening lsass.exe with OpenProcess.
